direction.raw_text: A woman's face BACKS INTO SHOT, her head resting against grimy wallpaper. She is tense, sweaty, wide-eyed with concentration. This is CLARICE STARLING, mid-20's, trim, very pretty. She wears Kevlar body armor over a navy windbreaker, khaki pants. Her thick hair is piled under a navy baseball cap. A revolver, clutched in her right hand, hovers by her ear. She raises a speedloader, in her left hand, locks it into her cylinder, twists and reloads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON A guest room door, with a small, wired pack attached to its knob. Suddenly, wish a sharp CRACK!, the knob explodes, and the door bursts open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MOVING SHOT as she runs around a corner, through a cloud of smoke. She shoulders aside the shattered door and rushes inside, gun at the ready in both hands...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - as she first sees, sitting on the edge of a bed - a FEMALE HOSTAGE. Black, late 20's, gagged, hands behind her back. Then, SWIVELLING... she sees a startled MALE SUSPECT, white, mid-20's, standing by a window with a rifle in his hands. He is turning towards her... Clarice drops into a combat crouch, gun extended, and shouts.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Freeze! FBI!

direction.raw_text: all natural SOUND suspended - as the Suspect faces her with a strange, pleading expression. The rifle is rising in his hands, but oddly enough, it is held across his chest, not pointing. Then another puzzling detail registers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: are taped to his gun, away from the trigger; he couldn't use it even if he tried. Suddenly we hear a metallic CLICK, which registers with unnatural amplification, as - Clarice reacts, drops to the floor, rolling sideways, and -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pulls a revolver out from behind her back, still in SLOW MOTION, raising it in her untied hands. She fires repeatedly, flames leaping from the muzzle; the SOUND is an echoing roar in these close quarters, but - Clarice has come up on one knee, beside an armchair, and is already firing back herself, two quick SHOTS, which send -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pitching over the bed, backwards, to shudder and lie still in a haze of gunsmoke. Clarice rushes to her, clamping one knee down on her gun hand, still keeping her covered in case of movement. HOLD for a few beats... then we hear the shrill blast of a WHISTLE from somewhere, off screen, as normal ACTION and SOUND are restored.

direction.raw_text: Clarice relaxes, lowering her gun. The lights brighten.

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Okay, people, good exercise...

direction.raw_text: we see that we're in some sort of auditorium, with the "hotel room" and its "corridor" built as a training set. JOHN BRIGHAM walks onto this set, thumbing a stopwatch. Mid-40's, ex- Marine. His T-shirt's lettering says "Firearms Instructor / FBI Academy."

direction.raw_text: A class of about forty young FBI trainees, of both sexes, begins to rise from their seats, mingling and chatting. Clarice nods amiably to the "Suspect", then gives her "Hostage" a hand up. It's ARDELIA MAPP, her roommate. Her broad, clever face breaks into a big smile, as they both remove ear plugs. Clarice's voice has just a soft trace of southern accent.

direction.raw_text: As Brigham joins them, Clarice can't resist a star pupil's little smile of pride. He frowns good-naturedly.

direction.raw_text: He takes out a steel-coiled grip flexer, drops it onto her palm.

direction.raw_text: He nods a direction, then moves off. Clarice, with her smile finally fading, looks out into the auditorium.

direction.raw_text: sits on the top step of the aisle, looking down at her. He is 53, strongly built. He rises impassively, exits through the back door. He carries a think manila envelope under one arm. Ardelia who is helping Clarice unbuckle her bullet-proof vest, follows her worried gaze.

direction.raw_text: They're reached his car. His driver stamps on a cigarette, climbs in behind the wheel. BURROUGHS, his assistant, says something into a walkie-talkie, then opens the back door. But Crawford pulls her aside, a hand on her shoulder. His intensity is scary.

dialogue.raw_text: Starling, Clarice M., good morning.

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, Mr. Crawford.

dialogue.raw_text: A job's come up and I thought about you. Not really a job, more of - an interesting errand. Walk me to my car, Starling.

dialogue.raw_text: We're trying to interview all of the serial killers now in custody, for a psychobehavioral profile. Could be a big help in unsolved cases. Most of them have been happy to talk to us. They have a compulsion to boast, these people... Do you spook easily, Starling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet.

dialogue.raw_text: The cannibal...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, well... Okay, right. I'm glad for the chance, sir, but - why me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're qualified and available. And frankly, I can't spare a real agent right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't expect him to talk to you, but I have to be able to say we tried... Lecter was a brilliant psychiatrist, and he knows all the dodges. (hands her the manila envelope) Dossier on him, copy of our questionnaire, special ID for you... If he won't talk, then I want straight reporting. How's he look, how's his cell look, what's he writing? The Director himself will see your report, over your own signature - if I decide it's good enough. I want that by 0800 Wednesday, and keep this to yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now. I want your full attention, Starling. Are you listening to me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be very careful with Hannibal Lecter. Dr. Chilton at the asylum will go over the physical procedures used with him. Do not deviate from them, for any reason. You tell him nothing personal, Starling. Believe me, you don't want Hannibal Lecter inside your head... Just do your job, but never forget what he is.

dialogue.raw_text: (a bit unnerved) And what is that, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Oh, he's a monster. A pure psychopath...

result.heading: INT.
location: BALTIMORE STATE HOSPITAL FOR THE CRIMINALLY INSANE

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) It's so rare to capture one alive. From a research point of view, Dr. Lecter is our most prized asset...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FREDERICK CHILTON looks up from her card. A smarmy little peacock, behind a vast desk; he's conceived an instant, hopeless letch for Clarice. He smiles, stroking her card with his beloved gold pen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know, we get a lot of detectives here, but I must say, I can't ever remember one so attractive...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: now wearing a more feminine skirt suit. Hair neatly coiled, elegant shoulder bag, briefcase. He has rudely left her standing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarice tries, unsuccessfully, to hide her distaste for him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Will you be in Baltimore overnight...? Because this can be quite a fun town, if you have the right guide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure it's a great town, Dr. Chilton, but my instructions are to talk to Lecter and report back this afternoon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause, sourly) I see. (beat) Let's make this quick, then. I'm busy.

direction.raw_text: Clarice flinches as a heavy steel gate CLANGS shut behind her, the bolt shooting home. Chilton walks ahead of her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lecter carved up nine people - that we're sure of - and cooked his favorite bits. We've tried to study him, of course - but he's much too sophisticated for the standard tests. And my, does he hate us! Thinks I'm his nemesis... Crawford's very clever, isn't he? Using you.

dialogue.raw_text: How do you mean, Dr. Chilton?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A pretty young woman, to turn him on? I don't believe Lecter's ever seen a woman in eight years. And oh, are you ever his "taste" - so to speak.

dialogue.raw_text: I graduated magna from UVA, Doctor. It's not a charm school.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. Then you should be able to remember the rules.

direction.raw_text: A darker, even grimmer area. Heavy grids over the lights. Distant SLAMMINGS and faint, hoarse SHOUTS. They walk briskly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands Clarice a small, dog-eared photo. Looking at it, she is stopped in her tracks. This pleases Chilton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns, pushes a button. A steel door BUZZES slowly open, and BARNEY - a big, impassive orderly - awaits them in an anteroom. On its walls: restraints, mouthpieces, Mace, tranquilizer guns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She holds out the photo. A beat. He grabs it, jaw twitching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns on his heel, goes. Barney smiles reassuringly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sensing her tension, he indicates a nearby security monitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarice nods gratefully. She looks down the long corridor, takes a deep breath, walks into it. He watches her go.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do not reach through the bars, do not touch the bars. You pass him nothing but soft paper - no pens or pencils. No staples or paperclips in his paper. Use the sliding food carrier, no exceptions. Do not accept anything he attempts to hold out to you. Do you understand me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to show you why we insist on such precautions... On the afternoon of July 8, 1981, he complained of chest pains and was taken to the dispensary. His mouthpiece and restraints were removed for an EKG. When the nurse bent over him, he did this to her...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The doctors managed to re-set her jaw, more or less, and save one of her eyes. His pulse never got over eighty-five, even when he ate her tongue. (pauses, he smiles) I keep him in here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly blocking him) Dr. Chilton - if Lecter feels you're his enemy - as you've said - then maybe I'll have more luck by myself. What do you think?

dialogue.raw_text: (annoyed) You might have suggested that in my office, and saved me the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When she's finished, bring her out.

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, I'm Barney. He told you, don't get near the bars?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his hand) Clarice Starling. Yes, he did.

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. Past the others, it's the last cell. Stay to the middle. I put out a chair for you.

dialogue.raw_text: I'm watching. You'll do fine.

Some are padded, with narrow observation slits, others are normal, barred... Shadowy occupants pacing, MUTTERING... Suddenly a dark figure in the next-to-last cell hurtles towards her, his face mashing grotesquely against his bars as he hisses.

Sparse, bolted- down furniture, many softcover books and papers. On the walls, extraordinarily detailed, skillful drawings, mostly European cityscapes, in charcoal or crayon. Clarice stops, at a polite distance from his bars, clears her throat.

direction.raw_text: Dr. Hannibal Lecter is lounging on his bunk, in white pajamas, reading an Italian Vogue. He turns, considers her... A face so long out of the sun, it seems almost leached - except for the glittering eyes, and the wet red mouth. He rises smoothly, crossing to stand before her; the gracious host. His voice is cultured, soft.

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Lecter... My name is Clarice Starling. May I talk with you?

direction.raw_text: She complies each time, trying to hide her fear. Dr. Lecter's nostrils lift, as he gently, like an animal, tests the air. Then he smiles, glancing at her card.

direction.raw_text: She sits in the folding metal desk-chair. He waits politely till she's settled, then sits down himself, faces her happily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pause, then Clarice takes the questionnaire from her case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A tense beat, then a smile from him, at this small boldness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She rolls him the questionnaire, in his sliding food tray. He rises, glances at it, turning a page or two disdainfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly he whips the tray back at her, with a metallic CLANG that makes her start. His voice remains a pleasant purr.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His every word has struck her like a tiny, precise dart. But she squares her jaw and won't give ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He steps backwards, then returns to his cot, becoming as still and remote as a statue. Frustrated, Clarice hesitates, then finally shoulders her bag and goes, leaving the questionnaire in his tray. But after just a few steps, as she passes -

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER You're sooo ambitious, aren't you...? You know what you look like to me, with your good bag and your cheap shoes? You look like a rube. A well- scrubbed, hustling rube with a little, taste... Good nutrition has given you some length of bone, but you're not more than one generation from poor white trash, are you Officer Starling...? That accent you're trying so desperately to shed - pure West Virginia. What was your father, dear? Was he a coal miner? Did he stink of the lamp...? And oh, how quickly the boys found you! All those tedious, sticky fumblings, in the back seats of cars, while you could only dream of getting out. Getting anywhere - yes? Getting all the way - to the F...B...I.

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER You're a tough one, aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Reasonably so. Yes.

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER And you'd hate to think you were common. My, wouldn't that sting! Well you're far from common, Officer Starling. All you have is the fear of it. (beat) Now please excuse me. Good day.

direction.raw_text: rushes into them, and he sweeps her up in a hug, spinning her around, the CAMERA SPINNING with them, and capturing both their laughing faces, before we abruptly return to -

dialogue.raw_text: Damn. Wish I had time for a social life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) Mr. Crawford?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Crawford, in a cardigan, sits in a wing chair in the book- lined study of his suburban home. He turns the pages of Clarice's memo as they talk. His tone is sharp.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've read your interim memo on Lecter. You sure you've left nothing out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's all there, sir, practically verbatim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She pauses, expecting some soft of approval for her cleverness.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Every word, Starling? Every gesture?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a bit heatedly) Right down to the kleenex I used. (he is silent) Sir, why? Is something wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He mentioned a name, at the very end. "Mofet..." Any followup on her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I spent all evening on the mainframe. Lecter altered or destroyed most of his patient histories, prior to capture. No record of anyone named Mofet. But "Split City" sounded like it might have have something to do with divorce. I tracked it down in the library's catalogue of national yellow pages. (glancing at her notes) It's a mini-storage facility outside Baltimore, where Lecter had his practice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well? Why aren't you there right now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, that's a field job. It's outside the scope of my assignment. And I've got a test tomorrow on -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you recall my instructions to you, Starling? What were they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To complete and file my report by 0800 Wednesday. But sir -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then do that, Starling. Do just exactly that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, what is it? There's something you're not telling me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Miggs has been murdered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (startled, upset) Murdered...? How?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The orderly heard Lecter whispering to him, all afternoon, and Miggs crying. They found him at bed check. He'd swallowed his own tongue... Chilton is scared stiff the family will file a civil rights lawsuit, and he's trying to blame it on you. I told the little prick your conduct was flawless. (beat) Starling...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm here, sir, I just - I don't know how to feel about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to feel any way about it. Lecter did it to amuse himself. Why not, what can they do? Take away his books for awhile, and no jello... (a bit softer) I know it got ugly today. But this is your report, Starling - take it as far as you can. On your own time, outside of class. Now carry on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as we hear the loud CLICK of Crawford hanging up. She stares at her receiver, stung by his abruptness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She slams her receiver into its cradle.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well God damn it! You old creep. Creepo son of a bitch. Let Miggs squirt you and see how you like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as he flips aside her memo, then rises, wearily. He leaves his study, flicking off the lamp, and pads away in his slippers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A private nurse, in white, stands marking a clipboard chart, as Crawford enters his tidy bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The nurse nods, hands him the chart, and goes. He glances at it, then sets it aside. He crosses to -
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take over, Patricia. You get some rest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: who lies in an elevated hospital bed. Nearby are an oxygen tank and mask, floral arrangements. Her breathing is shallow, very labored. Crawford looks down at his comatose wife for a long moment, tenderly brushes a strand of her hair back into place, then bends over to kiss her forehead. SOUND UPCUT - THUNDER and RAIN...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An orange neon sign, streaked with rain, identifies out location. It looms over a hurricane fence, topped with barbed wire. Inside, row on row of garage-sized, cinderblock sheds.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . YOW (V.O.) Unit 31 was leased for ten years. Pre-paid in full... The contract is in the name of "Miss Hester Mofet."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clarice, kneeling before a closed, roll-up metal door, takes a FLASH photo of its sealed padlock. EVERETT YOW, a fat, 60ish Chinaman, holds an umbrella over them both. He looks unhappy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She opens the padlock, using a fat ring of tagged keys, then sets aside both keys and lock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slinging her camera over a shoulder, she tugs at the handle, but the door won't budge. Another tug, harder - no good. Mr. Yow stoops to help, puffing hard, but it's firmly stuck. He sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarice crosses to her Pinto, which faces the shed, reaches in to turn on her headlights. Mr. Yow blinks in the sudden brightness. Then she opens her truck, rummaging inside, and returns with a bumper jack, a flashlight, and a rubber floor mat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gives him her flashlight and camera, drops the mat on the ground, then sets the bumper jack in place, under the center of the door. She pumps on the jack handle as the door SQUEALS slowly up, but it won't go higher than about 18 inches, despite all her exertions. She spreads out the rubber mat on the cement, takes the flashlight from Mr. Yow, then lies on the mat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So no one's been in here since - 1980?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . YOW Not to my knowledge. Privacy is a great concern to my customers. But, if you say this is an FBI matter...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't disturb anything, Mr. Yow, I promise. Be gone before you know it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . YOW We could return tomorrow, with my son. Or perhaps some workmen...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you hold these, please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clarice, backlit, peers under the door. She reaches in, makes a sweep with her flashlight. We catch shadowy outlines - boxes, then the flattened tires of a car...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of rain on the tin roof, and other noises, too - small RUSTLINGS. Mr. Yow's chubby face appears down beside Clarice's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarice turns onto her back, starts squirming under the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . YOW It smells like mice... I think I hear them, too - don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . YOW You're going in there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clarice pulls her head back out again, reaching to take her camera from him. She hands him a card, trying to appear nonchalant.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Yow, if this door should fall down -ha ha! - or anything else - would you be kind enough to call this number? It's our Baltimore field office. They know you're here with me... Do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . YOW Might I suggest tucking your pants into your socks? To prevent mouse intrusion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Good idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clarice squirms, on her back, through the narrow opening. As she squeezes all the way in, she snags one thigh on the metal edge of the door. She curses softly, shining her flashlight on her ripped khakis - there's a small streak of blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shines her light around. In its narrow beam, we see -
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . YOW (O.S.) Okay, Miss Starling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, Mr. Yow...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: spiderwebs, everywhere... high stacks of cardboard boxes... a few dusty pieces of furniture... the big car, oddly long and tall, covered with a tarp... Suddenly there's a scurrying of loud MUSICAL NOTES. Clarice turns, scared, her beam capturing... an old upright piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarice crawls a bit further. There's hardly room to stand, but she finally manages to wriggle upright, clawing away cobwebs, next to the car. Holding her light under one arm, she takes several FLASH photos of the shed's interior, ending with the car. Then, slinging her camera over the shoulder, she folds back the tarp, resting it on the roof. The resulting clouds of dust make her cough.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . YOW (O.S.) You're playing a piano, Miss Starling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That wasn't me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . YOW (O.S.) Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is an antique beauty, a 1931 Packard. It's very dusty, despite the tarp. Curtains close off the back passenger compartment, but there's a narrow gap in them. More mousy RUSTLINGS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: peers in through the gap, aiming her flashlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as the thin flashlight beam picks out: the broad back seat... as open album of lacy, old-fashioned Valentines... a crumpled lap rug, on the floor... and then a pair of women's shiny, high-heeled pumps... Above these, the hem of a fancy satin evening gown - and a pair of pale, stockinged legs. Clarice recoils, alarmed, then steadies herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leans down with her camera, takes a FLASH through the gap, then tries the door handle. Locked. So is the front door. She looks around, aiming her light, and locates a tangle of coat-hangers, sticking out of a carton of bric-a-brac. She pulls out one of these, straightens it quickly, bends the tip into a hook.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Yow? Oh Mr. Yow...? It looks like somebody is sitting in this car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . YOW (O.S.) Oh my! Oh my... Maybe you better come out now, Miss Starling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet! - just wait for me. (under the breath) Maybe in about two seconds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as she jams this tool inside the join at the top of the back passenger window, then fishes around till she can snag the inside door latch, pulling up. A satisfying CLICK. Clarice opens the door - it hits stacked boxes, and won't open far - then very cautiously leans inside, aiming her flashlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: revealing more of the evening gown... a pair of hands, in white, elbow-length gloves - one rests on the lap, the other atop a large, beaded, drawstring evening bag... thick strands of costume pearls over the breasts... and finally the white neck stub of a female mannequin. No face or head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sighs with relief. She takes a couple more FLASHES, then very carefully lifts out the Valentine album, holding it by the corners, and setting it atop the car. Then she eases herself inside, onto the back seat, as the springs SQUEAK loudly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: slides off the lap, brushing Clarice's thigh. Clarice starts a bit, then pokes at the gloved arm, hard. She peels back a bit of glove, revealing the white, synthetic elbow. She smiles, shaking her head at her own jumpiness, as she reaches over the mannequin's lap to loosen the evening bag's drawstring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares back at her, as the beaded material slides away. Clarice lurches back, gasping loudly, and several long, heart- pounding moments pass before she can make herself look more closely. The head bobs gently in a pool of alcohol, in a laboratory specimen jar. It is a man's head, but grotesquely transformed, by the addition of heavy makeup, earrings, and a sodden wig, into a woman's face. Over the years the makeup has smeared badly, and the pupils have gone almost milky white.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: staring at this terrible thing, is pleased to find herself quickly regaining control. She murmurs to herself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Toto, we're not in Kansas anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A loud clap of THUNDER, as a flash of LIGHTNING illuminates the eerie towers and barred windows of the asylum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ANGLE on Clarice as she climbs from her car, runs through heavy rain towards the main entrance, where a guard admits her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LECTER'S CELL AND CORRIDOR - NIGHT (DIM LIGHT) On a noiseless TV screen, an evangelist rants, waving his arms. Behind him, a swaying choir in gaudy robes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) It's an anagram, isn't it, Doctor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: TO Clarice, with her wet hair plastered flat, sitting on the corridor floor to one side of this TV, which has been stationed so that Dr. Lecter cannot avoid seeing it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hester Mofet... "The rest of me." Miss The-Rest-of-Me... Meaning, you rented that place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: he's lost in shadows; we can't see him. He doesn't respond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarice and the darkened call - as she tries again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The food carrier suddenly SWISHES out of the cell, making her jump up. In its tray is a clean, folded white towel. She hesitates, then crosses, takes this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits again, rubbing her wet hair. When he finally speaks, he's on the floor, too - a deeper, hunching darkness in the shadows, occasionally striped by the flickering TV light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Lecter slowly turns up the rheostat in his cell. As his lights rise, we see that the cell's been stripped bare. Gone are his books, drawings, mattress - even his toilet seat. She stands, too, startled. They face each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Dr. Lecter only smiles, enigmatically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Clarice stares at him, unsure how to respond -
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You put those - things in there. Paid for it in advance, ten years ago... Why, Dr. Lecter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Your bleeding has stopped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did - (she stops herself) It's nothing. A scratch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Why don't you ask me about Buffalo Bill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised, a beat) Why? Do you know something about him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER I might if I saw the case file. You could get that for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you tell me about "Miss Mofet?" You wanted me to find him. Or do I have to wait for the lab?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER (sighs) His real name is Benjamin Raspail. A former patient of mine, whose romantic attachments ran to, shall we say, the exotic...? I didn't kill him, merely tucked him away. Very much as I found him, in that ridiculous car, in his own garage, after he's missed three appointments. You'd have him under "Missing Person" - which, in poor Raspail's case, could hardly be more true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you didn't kill him, then who did?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Who can say...? Best thing for him, really. His therapy was going nowhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wouldn't it have been easier to just leave him for the police to find?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER And have them clomping about in my life? Oh dear, no... At that time I still had certain private amusements of my own. (beat) How did you feel when you saw him, Clarice? May I call you Clarice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Scared, at first. Then - exhilarated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Ahhh... Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because you weren't wasting my time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Do you have something you use, when you need to get up your courage? Memories, tableaux... scenes from your early life?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Next time I'll have to check.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Jack Crawford is helping your career, isn't he? Apparently he likes you. And you like him, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never thought about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Your first lie to me, Clarice. How sad. Tell me - do you think Crawford wants you, sexually? True, he's much older, but - do you think he visualizes... scenarios, exchanges...? Fucking you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That doesn't interest me, Doctor. And it's the sort of thing Miggs would ask.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Not anymore. (beat) Surely the odd confluence of events hasn't escaped you, Clarice. Crawford dangles you before me. Then I give you a bit of help. Do you think it's because I like to look at you, and imagine how good you would taste...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Or doesn't this all begin to suggest to you a kind of... negotiation? There's something Crawford can give me, and I want to trade for it. I even wrote to him, offering my help. But he hates me, so he won't deal directly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Punishment, you see. For Miggs. Just like that gospel program. When you leave, they'll turn the volume way up. Chilton does enjoy his petty torments.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who killed Raspail, Doctor...? You know, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER I've been in this room for eight years, Clarice. I know they will never, ever let me out while I'm alive. What I want is a view. I want a window where I can see a tree, or even water. I want to be in a federal institution, away from Chilton - and I want a view. I'll give good value for it. Crawford could do that for me, but he won't. You persuade him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost a whisper) Who killed your patient?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Oh, a very naughty boy. Someone you and Jack Crawford are most anxious to meet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Buffalo Bill...? (incredulous) Bill killed him, all those years ago...? That's impossible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Who is he stalking right now, Clarice? I wonder, don't you? How many more young women will have to die, before you trade with me...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: takes a long toke from a bong pipe. She is 21, a tall, big-boned, rather fleshy girl with long brown fair. Her head is on the lap of her boyfriend, CODY; they're sprawled on a couch in the den of her well-furnished apartment. The TV in on, with low SOUND.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to rise, but she pushes him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She rises, goes out the front door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This stuff's givin' me the munchies. Where's that bag of popcorn?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit. Left the groceries in the car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: okay, I'll go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Catherine straightens, with her bag of groceries, shutting her car's back door. She sees, a short distance away -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: standing at the open rear door of a brown panel truck. His right forearm is in a cast and sling; he is struggling, unsuccessfully, to hoist an armchair into the truck. Parked nearby, other cars, RVs, a boat on a trailer. A thin, breast- high fog fills the lot; arc lights make yellow pools. Catherine hesitates, then crosses towards the man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His voice is odd, strained, very soft. A fog lamp, set on end on the ground, distorts his features from below. We can't get a good glimpse of his face, but his body is plump, above average height; he's in his mid 30's. She sets down the bag, then together they easily lift the chair into the truck.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Help you with that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you? Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Let's slide it up, you mind?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE PANEL TRUCK - NIGHT He climbs inside the truck, ducking under a small hand winch, and grabs the chair. She hesitates again, but climbs in after him; together they slide the chair forward, behind the seats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, in the shadowy dark, he clubs her over the back of her head with his cast. She moans, slumps unconscious, sliding off the armchair to lie on her stomach. He pulls off his cast and sling, tosses them aside, then hops out of the truck, grabs his lamp, climbs back inside, and pulls the door shut. He bends over her face with the lamp. We hear her shallow BREATHING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He peels back the collar of her blouse, reading the size tag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He carefully slits her blouse up the back, with a pair of bandage scissors, peeling apart the two halves. There's no bra strap. He strokes her bare skin delicately, very happily.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you about a size 14?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gooood...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - on Catherine's grocery bag, as her blouse is tossed out beside it. SOUND of the truck's motor starting. The truck backs up, one rear wheel knocking over the bag, partly squashing it. Then is drives away, taillights shrinking, as a lone orange rolls slowly away from the bag...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON a large video screen, where a BLURRY image gradually sharpens, resolving into two separate pieces of fabric.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarice sits at a long table, with other trainees. Ardelia is beside her. Other tables and students in the background. Each trainee has his own microscope. Clarice is tired, but straightens, hearing -
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Electron microscopy reveals fiber "signatures" that are nearly as distinct as fingerprints...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Both of these blouses were worn by victims of Buffalo Bill. They were found in two different states, and four months apart. He always slits them up the back, like a funeral suit...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: successively CLOSER VIEWS of the cut fabric edges, until we are seeing individual threads, big as tree limbs. The cuts match.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) The bunching you see - this compression - is characteristic of scissor cuts, rather than a single blade. And, as you see - Bill always uses the same pair...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as John Brigham, the gunnery instructor, sticks his head in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Clarice Starling! Are you in here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clarice and Brigham walk briskly down the hall, passing other trainees. He carries a small canvas bag.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get your field gear, take stuff for overnight. You're goin' with Crawford.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some fishermen in West Virginia found an unidentified girl's body. It's a Buffalo Bill-type situation. Been in the water about a week, and Jack needs somebody that can print a floater. Think you can handle it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinking quickly) I'll need the big fingerprint kit... and the one-to-one Polaroid, the CU- 5, with film packs and batteries.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brigham steers as they pass hangars, parked planes, an airstrip. Clarice holds a big fingerprint kit and a weekend bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarice absorbs this in silence as they stop near an ancient, rather dilapidated Beechcraft. Its door is open, the twin props and beacons already turning. Brigham turns to her, holding out his small canvas bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarice opens the bag, stares at the big blue gun nestled in its shoulder holster. She looks up at him, touched.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods, climbs out. Then she looks back in at him. They're both moved by this rite of passage, but a little embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jack's pretty tough on you, isn't he? Impatient...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's got a lot on his mind besides Buffalo Bill... His wife, Bella, is real sick. Comatose... I'm tellin' you about it now, 'cause he may never.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're goin' in the field, so you gotta have full kit. Take this - it's my own...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wear it, don't ever leave it in your purse. Dry fire it whenever you get the chance. And do your exercises.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will... I promise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, I hope you never need a thing I've taught you. But you've got something... Jack sees it, I do too. If you ever need to, you can shoot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bless you, Starling...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - Out the plane's window, at the landscape far below. Wisps of cloud, a quilt of farms. Clarice turns from the window, looks at a think folder in her lap. The cover reads "Case File: / BUFFALO BILL." Clarice is moody, distracted. She hesitates, then opens the file, begins to scan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S - HER POV Police forms, some handwritten... Typed lab reports; we catch words, phrases: "Autopsy Protocols", "Histamine Analysis"... Grainy enlargements of bullet slugs, showing matched grooves... And then a stack of victim photos. The first one, taken from a good distance away, shows a nude female body, face down on a pebbly riverbank, surrounded by bits of litter. Clarice hesitates again, then flips this photo to look at the next. It makes her flinch, just slightly. Quickly she turns through several more photographs, trying hard to concentrate.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) He keeps them alive for three days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: shows Crawford standing over her, swaying with the plane's motion. Behind him, the open cockpit door, the pilot's back. Crawford sits, removing sunglasses. He rubs his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The pilot adjusts a valve. Crawford turns to her again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why, we don't yet know... There's no evidence of rape or physical abuse prior to death. All the mutilation you see there is post-mortem. (a beat; he glances at her) I'm hot, are you hot? Bobby, it's too damned hot back here...

dialogue.raw_text: Number One. Maybe there's a connection, maybe not. Lying and breathing are the same thing to Lecter. Number Two. If I'd sent you in there with something to hide from him, he'd have known it, instantly. He'd never have trusted you.

dialogue.raw_text: Number Three, I didn't bring you along today just because you can do first-rate forensics. If Lecter is becoming part of this case, you've got the most current read on him. Live right behind your eyes, today. Don't try to impose any patterns on this guy. Just stay open and let him show you...

dialogue.raw_text: Your West Virginia specimen gave us quite a bit of trouble, but I finally managed to narrow his species through chaetaxy - studying the skin.

dialogue.raw_text: I'm the one who found his perforating proboscis! Are you wearing a gun, right now? (Clarice nods) Ooh, cool! Can I see it? Can I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just ignore him. He's not a Ph.D.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on the sliced cocoon, as Roden uses tweezers and a dental probe to ease out the sodden chrysalis.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) The whole trick is to remove the chrysalis without destroying it... The wings are just like wet tissue paper...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: are hunched over a formica table, peering through square magnifiers into stainless trays. Clarice watches curiously. Of their two specimens, Pilcher's moth is in much better condition - a big brown creature, its wings outspread on towel paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up at her, shyly. A little moment passes between them, before Roden straightens, exultant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves aside for Clarice to get a closer look at Pilcher's specimen. She leans forward, intently.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (without looking up) What do you do when you're not detecting, Officer Starling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I try to be a student, Dr. Pilcher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ever get out for cheeseburgers and beer? The amusing house wine...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) Not lately. But maybe someday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Positive match!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're sure?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (points with his dental probe) West Virginia... Baltimore. Officer Starling, meet Mister Acherontia Styx.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the wide, furry, brown back of the moth. And there, right between the wing bases - wonderful and terrible to see - is nature's perfect reproduction of a ghostly human skull.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Better known to his friends as the Death's-head Moth...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) The Latin name comes from two rivers in Hell. Your man - he drops these girls into rivers, every time. Didn't I read that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as she looks up at him, awed, excited, almost trembling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the two men stare at her, puzzled, we hear a SOUND UPCUT - the wail of police SIRENS - and...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And there's no way - no natural way - these could've wound up in the bodies?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes his head) They live in Malaysia. In this country, they'd have to be specially raised, from imported eggs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause, then softly) Dr. Lecter...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .S. ROUTE 95 - DAY (AERIAL SHOT) An awesome armada of police vehicles swings through an intersection, while normal traffic is held back by highway patrol cruisers. The lead cars turn off, hit the entrance ramp to the freeway - SIRENS going, tires SQUEALING, red flashers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE on a speeding surveillance van, with long antennas and a small satellite dish, near the head of the motorcade.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Maybe we can trace how he buys the bugs, starting with U.S. Customs...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The van is crammed with an impressive array of hi-tech equipment, all CLICKING and HUMMING. Burroughs is talking quietly on a scrambler phone, while another agent works a computer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Maybe we can locate some of Raspail's old lovers. Maybe, someday...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: sit in swivel seats at the rear, by a big window. Clarice can't resit an occasional peak at the trailing motorcade, awed and a bit thrilled to be the center of so much attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarice looks at him, surprised.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: But for Catherine Martin, it all comes down to you and Lecter. You're the one he talks to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's already offered to help... What would happen if we just showed our cards - asked him for Bill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He offered to help, Starling, not to snitch. That wouldn't give him enough chance to show off. Remember, Lecter looks mainly for fun. Never forget fun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But if he knew we have so little time -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If we act too anxious, he'll make us wait. He'll let the Senator keep hoping, day after day, until Catherine finally washes up. That'd be the most fun of all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think he means it, this time. I think he'll deal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What would it take?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Transfer to a new prison. With a view of trees, he said, or even water... Can we swing that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes his head) State to federal jurisdiction... We can do it - eventually - but we'll never get all the clearances in time. Can you convince him a deal's already in place?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll back me up with some paperwork? (he nods) Then I'll try. But wouldn't this have more weight coming from the Senator herself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hesitates) She doesn't know what we're up to. And we can't afford to let her find out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's the mother, Starling. She can't possibly comprehend what Lecter is. She'd make the mistake of pleading with him. Begging him... He'd feast on her pain till the last second of that girl's life...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FOR THE CRIMINALLY INSANE - DAY Chilton approaches, walking briskly down a corridor in the administration wing. He looks quite agitated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chilton falls into step beside Clarice, who has her briefcase. He points his gold pen at her accusingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stares at him, with pity and distaste, till he lets go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks away, leaving him speechless with frustration and hostility. He clicks his pen, watching her go.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) We can't trust Frederick Chilton, either. He's greedy and ambitious. If he knew about Lecter's link to Bill, he's go straight to the newspapers...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you're doing, Miss Starling, is coming into my hospital to conduct an interview, and refusing to share information with me. For the third time!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Chilton, I told you - this is just routine follow-up on the Raspail case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's my patient! I have rights! (grabs her arm, stopping her) I'm not just some turnkey, Miss Starling. I shouldn't even be here this afternoon. I had a ticket to Holiday on Ice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm acting on instruction, Dr. Chilton. (handing him a card) This is the U.S. Attorney's number. Now please - either discuss this with him, or let me do my job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LECTER'S CELL AND CORRIDOR - DAY Dr. Lecter sits at his table, languidly sketching with charcoal on butcher paper. He uses his own hand and forearm as a model. His other drawings, books, and bedding have been restored.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarice, sitting again at the desk-chair, is taking papers from her briefcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarice looks down at her papers, taking a moment to collect her thoughts. She looks up at him again, evenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is silent. She rises, moves closer, carrying papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His face remains neutral. She puts the papers in his food tray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A measured beat, before he rises smoothly, crosses, and looks down at the papers, without touching them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him. A beat. They are standing uncomfortably close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarice cannot bear the feverish excitement in his eyes. She looks past him, hesitating again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly Dr. Lecter snarls, loudly, stretching. Clarice take a sharp step backwards before he smiles, turning his movement into an elaborate yawn. He gathers the papers from his tray.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Wouldn't you say, Clarice, that for a United States Senator, you're an odd choice of messenger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was your choice, Dr. Lecter. You chose to speak to me. Would you prefer someone else now? Or perhaps you don't think you can help us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER That is both impudent and untrue... Tell me, how did you feel when you viewed our Billy's latest effort? (beat; he smiles) Or should I say, his "next-to-latest"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By the book, he's a sadist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Life's too slippery for books, Clarice. Typhoid and swans came from the same God. (beat) Tell me, Miss West Virginia - was she a large girl?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Big through the hips. Roomy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They all were.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Mmm. And what else...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She had an insect deliberately inserted in her throat. That hasn't been made public yet. We don't know what is means.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Was it a butterfly?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause; staring at him) A moth... How did you predict that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER I'm waiting for your offer, Clarice. Enchant me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you help us find Buffalo Bill in time to save Catherine Martin, the Senator promises you a transfer to the V.A. hospital at Oneida Park, New York, with a view of the woods nearby. Maximum security still applies, but you'd have reasonable access to books.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Best of all, though - one week a year you'd get to leave the hospital and go here. (points to a map) Plum Island. Every afternoon of that week you can walk on the beach or swim in the ocean for up to one hour. Under SWAT team surveillance, of course...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Copy of the Buffalo Bill case file, copy of Senator Martin's terms. Her offer is final and non-negotiable. If Catherine dies - (she slides his tray through) You get nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER "Plum Island Animal Disease Research Center." Sounds charming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's just part of the island. It has a very nice beach. Terns nest there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Terns... If I help you, Clarice, it will be "turns" with us, too. Quid pro quo. I tell you things, you tell me things. Not about this case, though - about yourself. Yes or no? (she is silent) Yes or no, Clarice. Catherine is waiting. Tick-tock, tick-tock...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go, Doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER What's your worst memory of childhood? (she hesitates) Quicker than that. I'm not interested in your worst invention.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The death of my father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Tell me. Don't lie, or I'll know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was a town marshal... one night he surprised two burglars, coming out the back of a drugstore... They shot him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Killed outright?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. He was strong, he lasted almost a month. My mother - died when I was very young, so my father had become - the whole world to me... After he left me, I had nobody. I was ten years old.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER You're very frank, Clarice. I think - it would be quite something to know you in private life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quid pro quo, Doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER The significance of the moth is change. Caterpillar into cocoon into beauty... Billy wants to change, too, Clarice. But there's the problem of his size, you see. Even if he were a woman, he'd have to be a big one...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puzzled) Dr. Lecter, there's no correlation in the literature between transsexualism and violence. Transsexuals are very passive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Clever girl. You're so close to the way you're going to catch him - do you realize that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Tell me why.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER After your father's death, you were orphaned. What happened next? (Clarice drops her gaze) I don't imagine the answer's on those second-rate shoes, Clarice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I went to live with my mother's cousin and her husband in Montana. They had a ranch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER A cattle ranch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Horses - and sheep...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER How long did you live there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Why so briefly?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: - ran away...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Why, Clarice? Did the rancher fuck you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Did he try to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No...! Quid pro quo, Doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER Billy's not a real transsexual, but he thinks he is. He tries to be. He's tried to be a lot of things, I expect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You said - I was very close to the way we'd catch him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER There are three major centers for transsexual surgery: Johns Hopkins, the University of Minnesota, and Columbus Medical center. I wouldn't be surprised if Billy has applied for sex reassignment at one or all of them, and been rejected.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On what basis would they reject him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER The personality inventories would trip him up. Rorschach, Wechsler, House-Tree-Person... He wouldn't test like a real transsexual.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How would he test?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER That's enough, I think. Happy hunting. Oh, and Clarice - next time you will tell me why you ran away. Shall I summarize?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaken) Yes, Doctor. Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GUMB'S CELLAR - DAY VERY CLOSE ON a cocoon, split along its back, as a living Death's-head Moth wriggles torturously free. Trembling and damp, the new creature clings to a sprig of nightshade.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER (V.O.) You should try to obtain a list of males rejected from all three gender reassignment centers...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: we see a big wire cage, holding several of the moths. They crawl over the humus floor or feed at honeycombs, wings pumping lazily. In the distant background, the incongruous SOUND of show music.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER (V.O.) Check first the ones rejected for lying about criminal records...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ANGLE at about knee level, as we leave the cage, and begin to TRAVEL through this eerie, dimly-lit warren of a cellar. As we go - occasionally TURNING corners, or skirting the dark openings of unexplored passages - various objects loom briefly INTO VIEW, overhead - a stainless-steel work table... a big sink... jars of chemicals... neat racks of gleaming knives...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We pass a row of female mannequins, some nude, some wearing colorful leather jackets, designer knockoffs, in various stages of completion... then a huge maroon armoire, in Chinese lacquer; its double doors are slightly ajar... The jaunty background.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER (V.O.) Among those who tried to conceal their past, look for severe childhood disturbances, associated with violence... Possibly you'll find a childhood incarceration... Then go to their personality tests...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is growing even louder: Fats Waller singing "Bye Bye Baby." And now we hear something else, too - the rapid CLICKING of a sewing machine...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We TURN another corner, and there is Mr. Gumb himself. As we APPROACH, his wide back is to us; he's hunched over an old- fashioned sewing machine, humming cheerfully, and working a piece of material that we mercifully cannot see. A female wig rests near him on a head form. He wears a hairnet and a beautiful kimono, and pumps the treadle with his bare feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Next to Mr. Gumb is an antique phonograph - source of the MUSIC. His little dog, Precious, perches by his plump ankles. As we PASS Mr. Gumb, Precious scurries away from him, panting happily, and we FOLLOW the little dog down another corridor, the music starting to fade behind us...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the end of this final corridor, the cellar widens into a low-ceilinged chamber, with two additional doorways, and in the center of this is the gaping circle of the oubliette. Precious sniffs her way over to the edge - excited, tail wagging - than BARKS happily as we hear a hoarse, ghostly moan from below.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER (V.O.) Study their drawings, especially. Billy's house drawings will show no happy future... No baby carriage, out in the yard. No pets, no toys, no flowers, no sun...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER (V.O.) His females will be more crudely sketched than him males - but he'll compensate by adding exaggerated adornments... jewelry, big breasts... And his tree drawings - oh, his trees will be frightful...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER (V.O.) Billy hates his own identity, he always has - and he thinks that makes him a transsexual. But his pathology is a thousand times more savage... He wants to be reborn, Clarice. He will be reborn...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Pleeeeeeeease.....!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LECTER'S CORRIDOR - DAY MOVING ANGLE - CLOSE ON Dr. Lecter's slippered feet, which rest on the shelf of a rolling hand truck. RISING along his tilted form, we see that his ankles are linked by steel restraints... his legs, waist, upper torso, and arms are bound by heavy canvas webbing... beneath the webbing is a strait-jacket... and over his face is a hockey mask.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Bad news, Hannibal...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE shows that Dr. Lecter, on the handtruck, is being pushed down his corridor by Barney, and back into his open cell.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Gourmet magazine has rejected your recipe for braised kidneys...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LECTER'S CELL - DAY Chilton lounges on Dr. Lecter's cot, casually reading his large stack of private correspondence, and making notations with his gold pen on a little pad. Another orderly mops the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barney props the hand truck into position, then both orderlies go. Chilton finishes another letter, sighs happily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tossing letters onto the cot, he rises, crosses out into the corridor, and bends to remove a small tape recorder from underneath Clarice's desk. He waggles it triumphantly at Dr. Lecter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps you should have been less specific about what kind. (to Barney) Stand him by the toilet. Then leave us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Such a lot of correspondence! I can hardly wait to analyze it in more detail... But first things first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought she might be looking for a civil rights violation in Migg's death, so I bugged you... Not a word to me in all these years, Hannibal. Then Crawford sends his bit of fluff over here, and you just turn to jelly. It's too pathetic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Chilton, back in the cell, leans tauntingly close to the front of Dr. Lecter's mask.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You still think you're going to walk on some beach, and see the birdies? I don't think so, Hannibal... I called Senator Ruth Martin, and she never heard of any deal with you. She never heard of Clarice Starling, either. They scammed you, Hannibal...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ON Dr. Lecter's glittering eyes, behind their slits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When Crawford gets through milking you, he's giving you to Baltimore Homicide for the Raspail murder. And they're preparing some special surprises for you right now, in my electroshock room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LECTER'S POV (FRAMED BY EYE-SLITS) first looking at Chilton's moving lips... then LOWERING to his soft, white, inviting throat...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The Starling bitch wants you to rot here, in this little box, till your teeth fall out and you're soiling diapers. You've seen the old ones, Hannibal. They weep when their stewed peaches get cold. That'll be you, too. Unless - you trade with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as he sits chummily on the table.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There never was a deal with Senator Martin - but there is now. I've been on the phone for hours, Hannibal, on your behalf. Here's what you get: if you identify Buffalo Bill, and the girl is found in time, Senator Martin will have you transferred to Brushy Mountain State Prison, in Tennessee...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: AGAIN ON DR. LECTER'S EYES as they shift restlessly, away from Chilton - then suddenly lock onto something. They widen with interest.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) The Governor has already agreed. You get books, a view of the woods, and plenty of exercise time...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LECTER'S POV - EXTREME CLOSEUP On the cot, carelessly left there, lying half-hidden under the letters and the rumpled sheet... is Chilton's gold pen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) And best of all, you'd be out of Jack Crawford's reach, forever. The Senator will verify these terms on the phone, and guarantee them in writing...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LECTER as he stares a moment longer at the pen, then shifts his eyes towards Chilton. We can almost hear his brain clicking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat. Dr. Lecter is silent. Chilton sticks his face INTO SHOT, almost intimately close to the mask. He is agitated.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) In exchange, I get your full cooperation in publishing a professional account of this - my successful interviews with you. You publish nothing. And I get exclusive access to any material from Catherine Martin... So. Do you accept my demands? (pause) Answer me, Hannibal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll answer me now, or by God, you'll answer to Baltimore Homicide. Who is Buffalo Bill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . LECTER (pause; then softly) I'll tell the Senator herself. But only in Tennessee...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ANGLE - as the very impatient Crawford, clutching a folder, strides down a hall beside DR. DANIELSON - early 50's, severe, in a lab coat. Nurses, doctors, glance as they pass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danielson enters a cramped, stainless steel nurse's gallery, with Crawford following, and pours himself a cup of coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a black & white photo from his folder, slaps it down in front of Danielson. From our angle, we can't see it clearly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burroughs sticks his head in, looking for Crawford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burroughs hurriedly retreats. Crawford strains for patience.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . DANIELSON I'm not having a witch hunt here, Mr. Crawford! Our patients are decent, non-violent people with a real problem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Danielson, the man we want was never your patient. It would be someone you refused because he tries to conceal a record of criminal violence. Please, Doctor - time is eating us up. Just show me the ones you've turned away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DANIELSON (adamantly) Examination and interview materials are confidential. We've never violated an applicant's trust, and we never will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to see a violation? This is a violation...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Her name is Kimberly Jane Emberg, she was just ID'd. I met her on a slab in West Virginia. And sometime tomorrow, or tomorrow night, he's going to do the same thing to Catherine Martin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DANIELSON That's a childish, bullying stunt, Mr. Crawford. I was a battlefield surgeon, so you can put away your picture.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Phone, Jack. Director Burke.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snaps) In a minute!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look... search your own records, if you prefer. You can do it a lot faster than us, anyway. If we find Buffalo Bill through your information, I'll suppress it. Nobody has to know this hospital cooperated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DANIELSON I doubt very much that the FBI or any other government agency can keep a secret, Mr. Crawford. Truth will out... And then what? Will you give Johns Hopkins a new identity? Put a big pair of sunglasses on this building, and a funny nose?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, that's clever, Dr. Danielson. Very humorous. You like the truth? Try this. (right in his face, enraged) He kidnaps young women and kills them and rips their skin off. We don't want him to do that anymore. If you don't help me, just as fast as you can, then the Justice Department is going to ask publicly for a court order, We'll ask twice a day, just in time for the morning and evening news. And each one of our press conferences will focus on Dr. Danielson, over at Johns Hopkins, and how we're still hoping for his cooperation. And every time there's any news on the case - when Catherine Martin floats, when the next one floats, and the next one - why, we'll just issue another press release about good ol' Dr. Danielson, over at Johns Hopkins - complete with all his humorous fucking remarks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DANIELSON (pause; stiffly) It may be that - I could confer with my colleagues on this. And get back to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you, Doctor? That would be so kind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Crawford is on the scrambler phone. Burroughs watches silently.
direction.name: direction
